column3: The K200D feels solid and has a bigger grip than many of the other cameras in it's class, and overall feels very well-made. The kit lens is not perfect, but it's a damn sight better than many other kit lenses (although shadows in the corners are apparent in very bright scenes). Buttons are all nicely located and the autofocus is good, although occasionally hunts in very dim light. Grain in photos is well controlled, and the minimum f3.5 on the kit lens means you don't often need a higher ISO setting. Images are often sharper on the computer screen than on the screen, which is odd. The front element of the lens does not rotate on zoom or focus, making it easier to use polarising filters, and the included lens hood is excellent. Image stabilisation is built in-body and is effective, and battery life is EXEMPLARY - I've yet to change the battery from the ones that were put in when I bought the camera and the battery meter still reads full. Fantastic.

column3: This is a fantastic little SLR - even more so as I bought it as a kit with 18-55 and 55-300mm lenses.  Build quality is good, the only possible minus being carbon plastic mounts on the lenses, but this is really only an issue if you're a press photographer or plan to scale Everest with the camera hanging off your rucksack!  Handling is fine, although those with large hands (which I don't have) may find the diminutive size of the camera makes for fiddly button pressing.  That diminutive size, though, is another plus as this really is a very compact SLR and will fit into a small camera bag or pouch with no problem.  The fast (4.7 FPS) autodrive is terrific, meaning that, at a recent airshow, I got better shots than I've ever managed before, capturing even low flying fast jets, pin-sharp.  Where the camera really scores, though, is picture quality - sharp, 12.4MP photos with realistic colours and that 3D quality that makes the image seem to jump off the computer screen.  All in all, a little gem, which I am very glad I bought.
column5: The most annoying point for me is that the button to switch from taking to viewing pictures is situated at a point where my nose sometimes presses it accidently, changing mode unwittingly!  Now, I don't have a large nose, but I do shoot looking through the viewfinder with my left eye, so if you are a right-eyed photographer, it won't be a problem.  Other downsides are that the Live-View, like many SLRs, is not much cop, and although the viewfinder tells you the camera has focused (with a green hexagon lighting up) it doesn't indicate exactly what it's focused on.  I haven't found this too much of a problem - the viewfinder is sharp and bright enough to be able to see for yourself - but some might miss the confirmation.
